articles.headline: Pressured by China, Apple Apologizes for Warranty Policies
articles.snippet: Apple’s chief, Timothy D. Cook, said he would improve customer service after increasingly ferocious criticism from Chinese media outlets.
articles.abstract: Apple’s chief, Timothy D. Cook, said he would improve customer service after increasingly ferocious criticism from Chinese media outlets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, took the unusual step Monday of apologizing to Chinese customers over the company’s warranty policy and said he would improve customer service in the country.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Cypriots Feel Betrayed by European Union
articles.snippet: Many Cypriots are shocked and angry at what they consider their economic excommunication from the European project.
articles.abstract: Many Cypriots are shocked and angry at what they consider their economic excommunication from the European project.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Like a lot of Cypriots, Charalambos Alexandrou helped build his country into a modern Mediterranean paradise.

articles.headline: Rumors of a Cheap-Energy Jobs Boom Remain Just That
articles.snippet: Despite predictions that cheaper natural gas would generate big increases in factory payrolls, manufacturers are increasingly automated and still have two million fewer workers than in 2007.
articles.abstract: Despite predictions that cheaper natural gas would generate big increases in factory payrolls, manufacturers are increasingly automated and still have two million fewer workers than in 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: These are good times for Libbey, a 125-year-old American glassmaker that nearly went bankrupt four years ago. The company’s shares have risen to almost $20 from below $1, sales of its tableware are at a record high, and its energy-intensive factories saved more than $5 million in 2012 as natural gas prices fell.

articles.headline: Ruling Sets Up Pension Battle in Bankrupt City
articles.snippet: A judge’s ruling deferred a decision on whether bondholders could force retirees to share the pain of the bankruptcy of Stockton, Calif.
articles.abstract: A judge’s ruling deferred a decision on whether bondholders could force retirees to share the pain of the bankruptcy of Stockton, Calif.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal bankruptcy judge ruled on Monday that the city of Stockton, Calif., was eligible for court protection from its creditors, clearing the way for a battle over whether public workers’ pensions can be cut when the city they work for goes bankrupt.

articles.headline: A Slice of London So Exclusive Even the Owners Are Visitors
articles.snippet: For many recent superwealthy foreign buyers, London is just a stop in a peripatetic international existence that might also include New York, Moscow and Monaco.
articles.abstract: For many recent superwealthy foreign buyers, London is just a stop in a peripatetic international existence that might also include New York, Moscow and Monaco.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — An odd thing was happening, or rather not happening, as dusk fell the other day across Belgravia, home to some of the world’s most valuable real estate: almost no one seemed to be coming home. Perhaps half the windows were dark.

articles.headline: A $25 Million Question Over a Bid for Dell
articles.snippet: The Blackstone Group told Dell that it would not even consider bidding unless Dell offered to pay the firm’s expenses, up to a whopping $25 million.
articles.abstract: The Blackstone Group told Dell that it would not even consider bidding unless Dell offered to pay the firm’s expenses, up to a whopping $25 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is Stephen Schwarzman’s Blackstone Group really bidding for Dell? Or is it part of a bizarre, high-stakes charade?

articles.headline: Japan Shifts From Pacifism as Anxiety in Region Rises
articles.snippet: A mock island invasion exercise is the latest sign that worries over China and North Korea are pushing Japan away from pacifism.
articles.abstract: A mock island invasion exercise is the latest sign that worries over China and North Korea are pushing Japan away from pacifism.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE ISLAND, Calif. — The Japanese soldiers in camouflage face paint and full combat gear were dropped by American helicopters onto this treeless, hilly island, and moved quickly to recapture it from an imaginary invader. To secure their victory, they called on a nearby United States warship to pound the “enemy” with gunfire that exploded in deafening thunderclaps.

articles.headline: A Building Not Just Green, but Practically Self-Sustaining
articles.snippet: The Bullitt Center in Seattle is an experiment in sustainability, using recycled rainwater, solar panels and composting toilets.
articles.abstract: The Bullitt Center in Seattle is an experiment in sustainability, using recycled rainwater, solar panels and composting toilets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When an office building here that bills itself as the world’s greenest officially opens later this month, it will present itself as a “living building zoo,” with docents leading tours and smartphone-wielding tourists able to scan bar codes to learn about the artfully exposed mechanical and electrical systems.
